note_text:
Admission Date:  [**2103-7-3**]              Discharge Date:   [**2103-7-3**]

Date of Birth:  [**2069-7-23**]             Sex:   M

Service: NEUROSURGERY

Allergies:
Aleve

Attending:[**First Name3 (LF) 78**]
Chief Complaint:
acute onset headache

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
[**2103-7-3**] Cerebral Angiogram


History of Present Illness:
Mr. [**Name14 (STitle) **] is a 33 yo RH man without a relevant PMH p/w an acute
onset headache and LEFT cerebellar bleed with mass effect on 4th
ventricle.

He woke up at 6:00 am and was at his baseline. He did not have
any breakfast/ coffee. He had notrouble walking in the house or
reaching for his tooh brush/ glass of water. Suddenly, he
started
with a [**9-30**] headache at 10:00 am. He had never had this type of
a headache before. It was behind his eyes and constant (not
throbbing). It did not radiate. He took a tylenol and it
improved
to 9/ 10. He could not walk around anymore. He was unsteady
(cannot tell if leaning to the LEFT) and nauseated.

Eventually he vomited several times. His headache did not
improve. He did not have a blurry vision, but developed
photophobia. He had not had any drugs and has no hx of cocaine /
marihuana use. He does not have a hx of HTN/ prior CNS bleeds/
aneurisms/ brain tumors or a FH of any of those conditions.

He called EMS and was taken to OSH. His CTCNS showed a LEFT
cerebellar bleed with 4th ventricle compression. He received PHT
load 1.5 g iv (no seizure activity recorded) and was transferred
to [**Hospital1 18**]. His SBPs were normal. His coags were normal too.

Review of systems is notable for the absence of loss of vision,
blurred vision, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, tinnitus or
hearing abnormalities or problems with smell. Denies
difficulties
producing or comprehending speech.

Denies focal weakness, numbness, parasthesiae. No bowel or
bladder incontinence or retention. Denies difficulty with gait.
On general review of systems, the pt denies recent fever or
chills,sleep deprivation or any aggravating factor that may
precipitate the episodes.  No night sweats or recent weight loss
or gain. Denies cough, shortness of breath.  Denies chest pain
or
tightness, palpitations.  Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea,
constipation or abdominal pain.  No recent change in bowel or
bladder habits.  No dysuria.  Denies arthralgias or myalgias.
Denies rash.

Physical Exam:
On Admission:
PE:  70 153/85 18 99
GCS 15.
Gen: Lying in bed, HA 3/ 10 now.
HEENT: NC/AT, moist oral mucosa
Neck: supple, no carotid or vertebral bruit
Back: No point tenderness or erythema
CV: Nl S1 and S2, no murmurs/gallops/rubs
Lung: Clear to auscultation bilaterally
Abd: Soft, nontender, non-distended.  No masses or megalies.
Percussion within normal limits. +BS.
Ext: no edema, no DVT data. Pulses ++ and symmetric.
.

MS:
General:  alert, awake but drowsy,
Orientation:  oriented to person, place, date, situation.
.

Executivefunction:
DOW backwards +: in less than 20 seconds.

*Follows simple axial and appendicular commands: closes and
opens
his eyes, shows me the tongue. Gives me a thumb or a provides
and
releases a grip at command.

*Follows three step commands: "take this piece of paper with
your
right hand, fold it into two parts and return it to me with the
left hand".

Memory: [**2-21**] and Recalls [**2-21**] when given choices at 5 min.

Speech/Language: fluent w/o paraphasic (phonemic or semantic)
errors; comprehension, repetition, naming (high and low
frequency
objects): normal. Prosody: normal. Understands the passive
voice:
"the kid killed the lion".
.
Praxis/ agnosia: Able to brush teeth. Able to recognize I am
brusing my teeth. Able to mimic me brushing my teeth.
.
No field cuts: to red pin in different quadrants.
No extinction to visual or tactile stimuli or to a combination
of
both.

Able to tell how many people there are in the room .
.

CN:
I: not tested
II,III:  VFF to confrontation, PERRL 3mm to 2mm,  fundus w/o
papilledema. No red desaturation. OD and OS 20/ 20. He does have
bilateral endgaze horizontal nystagmus that beats to the side in
the direction where the pt is gazing and does not fatigue.
III,IV,VI: EOMI, no ptosis. Normal pursuit.
V:  sensation intact V1-V3 to LT.
VII:  Facial strength intact/symmetrical
VIII:  hears finger rub bilaterally
IX,X:  palate elevates symmetrically, uvula midline
[**Doctor First Name 81**]:  SCM/trapezeii [**4-25**] bilaterally
XII:  tongue protrudes midline, no dysarthria
.
Motor:
Normal bulk.
Tone: normal.
No tremor, no asterixis or myoclonus. No pronator drift:
.
       Delt;C5 bic:C6 Tri:C7 Wr ext:C6 Fing ext:C7
Left    5      5      5       5          5
Right   5      5       5       5          5
.
        IP: Quad:  Hamst: Dorsiflex: [**Last Name (un) 938**]:Pl.flex
Left    5      5      5           5          5
Right   5      5      5           5          5
.

.
       Bicip: Tric: Brachial: Patellar:  Achilles   Toes:
Right   2        2         2          2     2   DOWNGOING
Left    2        2         2          2     2   DOWNGOING
.
Sensation: Intact to light touch, vibration, and temperature.
Propioception: normal.
.
Coordination: Surprisingly preserved given his bleed.
*Finger-nose-finger: ataxic on the LEFT
*Rapid Arm Movements normal.
*Fine finger tapping: normal. Finger to crease normal too.
*Heal to shin: normal.
*I did not stand him up to assess truncal ataxia/ Gait/Romberg

K-3.5 Cl-106 HCO3-24 AnGap-16

Radiology Report CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST Study Date of [**2103-7-3**]
7:03 PM
Wet Read: JKSd TUE [**2103-7-3**] 8:31 PM
stable appearance of left cerebellar hemorrhage with surrounding
vasogenic
edema with mass effect on the fourth ventricle and effacement of
basilar
cisterns. slight improvement of previously described mild
hydrocephalus s/p catheter placement via right frontal approach.
no new acute hemmorhage

Radiology Report CTA HEAD W&W/O C & RECONS Study Date of
[**2103-7-3**] 1:45 PM
Preliminary Report !! WET READ !!  Unchanged left cerebellar
hemorrhage extending into 4th ventricle with mild hydrocephalus.
This appears to be secondary to an AVM supplied by left PICA,
AICA, and SCA. Multifocal venous drainage, including a venous
varix. 3D reformats pending.





Brief Hospital Course:
Pt underwent aggiography on [**7-3**] showing a left cerebellar AVM,
an EVD was also placed. No operating rooms were available for
emergent embolization and the patient was transferred to [**Hospital1 112**] for
the procedure.

Medications on Admission:
Alprazolam PRN

Discharge Medications:
1. Propofol 10 mg/mL Emulsion Sig: 5-50 mcg/kg/min Intravenous
TITRATE TO (titrate to desired clinical effect (please specify))
as needed for sedation for continuous days.
2. Hydromorphone 2 mg/mL Syringe Sig: [**12-23**] ml Injection Q3H
(every 3 hours) as needed for pain.
3. Famotidine(PF) in [**Doctor First Name **] (Iso-os) 20 mg/50 mL Piggyback Sig:
Twenty (20) ml Intravenous Q12H (every 12 hours).
4. Cefazolin in Dextrose (Iso-os) 1 gram/50 mL Piggyback Sig:
One (1) g Intravenous Q8H (every 8 hours) as needed for EVD.


Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care

Discharge Diagnosis:
Left Cerebellar AVM


Discharge Condition:
Stable, Alert and oriented, NON-AMBULATORY, must stay flat while
femoral arterial sheath is in place.


Discharge Instructions:
Transfer to [**Hospital1 112**] for emergent embolization on left cerebellar
AVM. Pt is to remain lying flat as femoral arterial sheath is in
place. NPO

Followup Instructions:
Please all the office of Dr.[**First Name (STitle) **] at ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 88**]  for a
follow-up visit
